title: 3 Creative and Simple DIY Suncatcher Projects

steps.title: Cut several loops of bracelet-size memory wire.
steps.content: Cut several loops of bracelet-size memory wire. Use a pair of heavy duty wire cutters to do this. Memory wire is very hard, and it can ruin a pair of more delicate jewelry-making wire cutters.

steps.title: Use a pair of round nose pliers to fold the end of the memory wire into a loop.
steps.content: Use a pair of round nose pliers to fold the end of the memory wire into a loop. [1] X Research source Pinch the end of your memory wire with the tips of your round nose pliers. Twist the pliers away from yourself to form, but don't close the loop all the way.

steps.title: Slip a faceted bead onto a headpin.
steps.content: Slip a faceted bead onto a headpin. [2] X Research source You can use the standard teardrop shape, or something more interesting, such as a ball, heart, or star. For best results, use a crystal or glass bead; it will catch and reflect the light much better than a plastic one. This only works for beads that have a hole going straight up and down through them, and not for the pendant-style beads.

steps.title: Trim the headpin down to ¼-inch (0.64-centimeters), then use a pair of round nose pliers to twist the tip into a loop.
steps.content: Trim the headpin down to ¼-inch (0.64-centimeters), then use a pair of round nose pliers to twist the tip into a loop. Cut the head pin with a pair of wire cutters (you can use jewelry making wire cutters here).Next, grip the tip of the headpin with your pliers, and roll it towards the bead to form a loop. [3] X Research source If the loop is off-centered or crooked, use a pair of needle nose pliers to fix it. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Slip the headpin onto the memory wire, then close the memory wire's loop all the way.
steps.content: Slip the headpin onto the memory wire, then close the memory wire's loop all the way. Use a pair of needle nose pliers to open the loop on the memory wire, if needed. Slip the headpin onto the memory wire's loop, then use your needle nose pliers to close it again.

steps.title: Slip beads onto the memory wire.
steps.content: Slip beads onto the memory wire. [5] X Research source You can use all one type of bead, or experiment with different shapes, sizes, and colors. For example, you could use seed beads, small faceted beads, and large faceted beads.

steps.title: Twist the other end of your memory wire into a loop.
steps.content: Twist the other end of your memory wire into a loop. [6] X Research source Use the same technique as before: pinch the end of the memory wire with your round nose pliers, then roll it into a loop.

steps.title: Slip some string through the loop.
steps.content: Slip some string through the loop. [7] X Research source Tie the ends of the string to form a loop, then hang it from a hook.

steps.title: Find a plastic lid.
steps.content: Find a plastic lid. The best type of lid to work with is the kind that comes from a yogurt, butter, or margarine container. Make sure that the lid is clean and dry.

steps.title: Spread a thick layer of clear school glue over the bottom of the lid.
steps.content: Spread a thick layer of clear school glue over the bottom of the lid. Turn the lid over so that the inside is facing you. Fill the bottom with a thick layer of clear school glue. [8] X Research source Make sure that there aren't any gaps or holes in the glue, or your suncatcher will fall apart. It may seem as though you are using more glue than necessary, but clear glue tends to shrink a lot as it dries. [9] X Research source Do not use a clear, industrial-strength glue for this; you want to be able to remove the suncatcher from the lid when you are done. White school glue may also be used, but your finished suncatcher may look cloudy and not sparkle as much. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Arrange glass, flat-backed gems in the lid.
steps.content: Arrange glass, flat-backed gems in the lid. You can arrange them randomly or in a pattern, but make sure that you fill the entire bottom of the lid in an even layer. To make a more interesting looking suncatcher, experiment with different sizes and colors. Make sure that the flat size of the gems is facing down. Try planning out your pattern before arranging it in the glue.

steps.title: Fill the lid the rest of the way with clear school glue.
steps.content: Fill the lid the rest of the way with clear school glue. Do not skimp on the glue during this step; this is what will hold your suncatcher together. Make sure that you fill all of the cracks between the gems, and don't worry if the glue covers the gems; the glue will dry clear. [11] X Research source [12] X Research source

steps.title: Wait 2 to 4 days for the glue to dry.
steps.content: Wait 2 to 4 days for the glue to dry. [13] X Research source [14] X Research source Do not disturb the suncatcher during this time. If it tends to get very dusty where you live, consider placing a cardboard box over the lid to keep the glue clean and dust-free.

steps.title: Carefully peel the lid off of the suncatcher.
steps.content: Carefully peel the lid off of the suncatcher. Turn the suncatcher over, so that the back is facing you, and let it finish drying. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Thread some clear thread through a thick part of your suncatcher with a needle.
steps.content: Thread some clear thread through a thick part of your suncatcher with a needle. Find an area near the edge of the suncatcher where the glue is thick. Thread some clear string through a needle, then push the needle through the glue. [16] X Research source Tie the ends of the string into a loop.

steps.title: Hang the suncatcher indoors in front of a window.
steps.content: Hang the suncatcher indoors in front of a window. You can hang the suncatcher from a suction cup that has a hook on it, or you can hang it from the window latch. [17] X Research source Do not let this suncatcher get wet. The glue will dissolve.

steps.title: Cut two pieces of contact paper, peel the backing off of one, and set it down in front of you, sticky-side-up.
steps.content: Cut two pieces of contact paper, peel the backing off of one, and set it down in front of you, sticky-side-up. Make sure that both pieces of contact paper are the same size. You will be sticking them together in the end to seal your suncatcher.

steps.title: Cut or tear colorful tissue paper into small pieces.
steps.content: Cut or tear colorful tissue paper into small pieces. [18] X Research source The pieces don't all have to be the exact same size and shape, but they should all be around 1 inch (2.54 centimeters).

steps.title: Place the tissue paper pieces on top of the sticky side of the contact paper.
steps.content: Place the tissue paper pieces on top of the sticky side of the contact paper. Don't worry about making a specific shape just yet; focus instead on the size and the design. You can overlap the pieces, if you want to, but try not to leave any gaps. [19] X Research source

steps.title: Peel the backing off of the second piece of contact paper, and place it on top.
steps.content: Peel the backing off of the second piece of contact paper, and place it on top. Run your hands across the contact paper to smooth out any air bubbles and to seal the design in.

steps.title: Cut your shape out.
steps.content: Cut your shape out. You can draw your shape first, if you want to. Don't worry if the tissue paper extends past your design; the goal is to completely fill your design with color. [20] X Research source

steps.title: Punch a hole into the top of your suncatcher, then thread some string through it.
steps.content: Punch a hole into the top of your suncatcher, then thread some string through it. You can also use fishing line, yarn, or ribbon.

steps.title: Tie the ends of the string together to form a loop, then hang your suncatcher in a bright window.
steps.content: Tie the ends of the string together to form a loop, then hang your suncatcher in a bright window. Keep your suncatcher indoors and don't let it get wet, or it will fall apart.

steps.title: Finished.
steps.content: Finished.
